text.*:
Healthcare in Cyprus accounted for 7% of its GDP in 2014.[1] Between 2010 and 2014, health care spending increased from $1,705 per capita to $2,062 per capita.[2][3] Cyprus has a multi-payer health care system that consists of a public and private sector.[2] The public sector is funded by payroll, earnings taxes, and employer contributions.[2] The public sector healthcare provides social insurance for the employed, self-employed, and for several types of civil servant.[2]

Contents

  • 1 Health Insurance
  • 2 History
  • 3 Okyy
  • 4 Hospitals
  • 5 See also
  • 6 References

Health Insurance[edit]

The current dual sector system is in the process of being replaced with a National Health System that aims to provide universal coverage.[4] The National Health System is estimated to save €292 million from 2016-2025 compared to the predicted expenditures of the current system.[4] The public health sector managed by the Ministry of Health provided free services to approximately 83% of the population.[5] Public coverage includes dental, mental health and pharmaceutical services, as well as general public health resources.[6]

The three government bills and regulations introducing the national health system, Gesy, were agreed by parliament on 16th June 2017. Is is to be fully operational by July 1, 2020.[7]

History[edit]

In 2013 Cyprus decided to establish a national health care system, with support from creditors of the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank, and European Commission.[8] The National Health System is predicted to increase coordination, reduce waste, and be more fiscally responsible.[4] Inefficiencies in the system include overlapping services between the public and private health service providers and “poor communication and coordination” between the sectors.[6] Cyprus ranks the highest among European Union nations on out-of-pocket health spending.[6][9] Public healthcare operates with the state’s Ministry of Health providing control and funding.[6] Cyprus outperforms the EU average of dentists per capita (91 for every 100,000 people) and underperforms in pharmacists per capita (21 for every 100,000 people).[6]

George Pamporidis, the Minister of Health, announced in September 2015 that he intended to establish a National Health Service by 2017. He has previously pledged to clear our corruption in Cyprus' public hospitals.[10] Establishment of an operational NHS was a promise Cyprus made as part of the bailout programme with the Troika of international lenders. Pamporidis proposed a 2% special tax (1% for employers and 1% for employees) to finance a "mini-NHS".[11]


The Euro health consumer index ranked Cyprus 26th of 35 European countries in 2015, commenting that it did not really have a public healthcare system in the general European meaning of the term. [12]

Okyy[edit]

Sir David Nicholson was appointed chairman of the newly-established State Health Services Organisation (Okyy) in 2018.[13]
